description.narrative: The programme will support the legal reform process so that new laws safeguard the best interests of the child in contact with the civil, criminal or administrative justice system, including through the provision of child-sensitive procedures and information. It will further contribute to strengthening justice professionals' capacity to work with children in conflict with the law. It will also contribute to the development of policies and services to protect the rights of children in contact with the law â€”child victims/witnesses in particular â€” in order to reduce obstacles these children face in accessing justice and to prevent secondary victimization. To facilitate the implementation of all rights under the Convention on the Rights of the Child and under national laws, the programme will promote a participatory approach so that marginalized children have a voice in combating discrimination and experience the realization of their right to an effective remedy. This will be accomplished through measures including the provision of child-sensitive alternative mechanisms to solving disputes and seeking redress as well as the provision of appropriate reparation measures. This component will continue to support strengthened independent monitoring of child rights by the National Human Rights Defender's Office (HRDO), including through enhancing direct access of children to the HRDO and preparing specialized child rights reports to the President and Parliament. The role of NGOs as part of an independent monitoring system will be promoted. This component will also enable a more child-oriented approach to policy, programme and service design at all levels following relevant institutional mandates. Service provision will increasingly focus on the specific needs of the child and on better referral systems, with the expected result of a sharpened equity focus and greater progress in the realization of the rights of the most vulnerable., which contributes to Access To Justice, Access To Justice (Covid), Justice For Children, Prevention And Response Services For Violence Against Children, Prevention And Response Services For Violence Against Children (Covid), Violence, Exploitation And Abuse. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2020, the justice system adequately responds to violations of children's rights, and a system is developed to recognize and prevent violence, abuse and neglect of children.

description.narrative: Justice, Law and Order policy, planning and administration

title.narrative: UNICEF Programmes in Armenia (Access to Justice)
UNICEF Contract Awards through the UN Global Marketplace
Armenia 2020 Annual Report on Results for Children

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: The programme will support the legal reform process so that new laws safeguard the best interests of the child in contact with the civil, criminal or administrative justice system, including through the provision of child-sensitive procedures and information. It will further contribute to strengthening justice professionals’ capacity to work with children in conflict with the law. It will also contribute to the development of policies and services to protect the rights of children in contact with the law —child victims/witnesses in particular — in order to reduce obstacles these children face in accessing justice and to prevent secondary victimization. To facilitate the implementation of all rights under the Convention on the Rights of the Child and under national laws, the programme will promote a participatory approach so that marginalized children have a voice in combating discrimination and experience the realization of their right to an effective remedy. This will be accomplished through measures including the provision of child-sensitive alternative mechanisms to solving disputes and seeking redress as well as the provision of appropriate reparation measures. This component will continue to support strengthened independent monitoring of child rights by the National Human Rights Defender’s Office (HRDO), including through enhancing direct access of children to the HRDO and preparing specialized child rights reports to the President and Parliament. The role of NGOs as part of an independent monitoring system will be promoted. This component will also enable a more child-oriented approach to policy, programme and service design at all levels following relevant institutional mandates. Service provision will increasingly focus on the specific needs of the child and on better referral systems, with the expected result of a sharpened equity focus and greater progress in the realization of the rights of the most vulnerable.

description.narrative: UNICEF worked to strengthen the capacities of the social service workforce professionals, judges, prosecutors, investigators and police to protect children at risk or victims of violence. Support to the Council on Justice for Children continued to strengthen its capacities as a platform of coordinated planning, implementation and monitoring of actions to end violence. UNICEF partnered with the Chamber of Advocates of Armenia to enhance the quality of legal aid to children. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:19/01/2020

title.narrative: Country has a national, multi-sectoral plan(s) or strategy(ies) for coordinated action to prevent and respond to violence against children that meets key criteria for quality, according to status of plan.

baseline.value: Armenia is a pathfinding country of Global Partnership to End Violence Against Children; no national action plan available

target.value: 2020:National action plan to end violence against children adopted

actual.value: 2019:In 2019 the Council of Justice for Children facilitated wide consultation process to develop and cost a national action plan to end violence against children. General provisions of the plan were incorporated into Human Rights Strategy and Action Plan for 2020-2022 and adopted. Sector-specific action

title.narrative: Country has a functioning, national, multi-sectoral, multi-stakeholder coordination mechanism tasked with overseeing national plans or strategies to prevent and respond to violence against children and adolescents, with child and adolescent participation.

baseline.value: Coordination mechanism established but not functional

target.value: 2020:Multi-sectorial multi-stakeholder coordination mechanism is tasked with overseeing national plans to prevent and respond to violence against children and includes participation of children and adolescents

actual.value: 2019:Council of Justice for Children under the Ministry of Justice, supported by UNICEF, is a multi-sectorial and multi-stakeholder coordination mechanism. Council is chaired by the Deputy Minister of Justice and acts as the coordinationplatform for access to justice for children and violence against chi

title.narrative: Legislation with bylaws and regulations is developed and amended in line with international child rights standards, including the UN Guidelines on Justice in Matters involving Child Victims and Witnesses of Crime

baseline.value: Legislation is in place, but fragmented and not in line with UN standards

target.value: 2020:Amendments to legislation adopted, bylaws and regulations developed

actual.value: 2019:With UNICEF's support child-friendly justice procedures have been incorporated into three major new draft pieces of legislation - Criminal Code, Code of Criminal Procedure and Penitentiary Code. Codes will be presented to the Parliament for adoption in 2020.

title.narrative: Existence of specialized justice for children systems, such as capacity building and standards-setting within criminal and civil justice systems

baseline.value: No specialized curricula and standards available in criminal and civil justice systems

target.value: 2020:Specialized curricula integrated into Justice Academy, Police Academy and School of Advocates' training programs

actual.value: 2019:Partnership with the Chamber of Advocates was established and agreement to introduce specialized curricula reached, UNICEF ECARO Guidelines on Child-Friendly Legal Aid translated and disseminated, training course is in the process of development.

title.narrative: Mechanism for direct access for children to the Human Rights Defender

baseline.value: Special Unit in place but not fully functional

target.value: 2020:Outreach campaign is conducted to increase children's awareness on CRC and applying to the Ombudsman to obtain effective remedy in case of violation of their rights

actual.value: 2019:HRD's outreach activities involved all children in closed institutions. In addition to that, manual on child rights and redress mechanisms was developed by HRD for school teachers and will be incorporated into curricula starting from 2020.
